The average breath acetone concentration for five consecutive sampling of 60-min interval was 0.92ppmv and the corresponding RSD was 12.3%, indicating a significant difference from a group of healthy persons. Additionally, for the diagnosis of diabetes, ketone bodies in urine have been measured especially concentration of acetoacetate, and acetone is produced by the decarboxylation of acetoacetate. Therefore, the determination of breath acetone and urine acetone in fasting condition is one of the most suitable approaches for evaluating the validity of the proposed needle extraction method. First, breath and urine acetone in four healthy male individuals were monitored for three days just before the fasting test.
